For this would be in perfect 
contact with the glass;
and in this case I never 
found either air or water 
to get into the vessel to 
disturb my experiment“.
From these few facts 
thus briefly but clearly 
described the whole of my 
conclusions might have 
been deduced with as much 
justness as from the more 
extended and various obser-
vations upon which I have 
hitherto rested them. If,
in Dr. Priestly’s experiments 
mercury could not be brought in 
perfect contact with glass
